item.title: Overcoming Latin America’s Mounting Debt Crises
item.description: Climate finance and green investments will achieve little in debt-strapped economies unless such measures are tied to systemic reform. Latin American and Caribbean countries do not need incremental pledges; they need an overhaul of global financial governance.

item.title: Deliveroo Politics
item.description: According to conventional wisdom, populists are continuing to be elected because democracies have failed to "deliver." Why, then, are populists winning even in countries where economic growth is strong and inequality is stable or declining?

item.title: Is the Global Economy as Resilient as It Seems?
item.description: The current global economic outlook is decidedly mixed. Despite continued strength, advanced economies are grappling with rising debt burdens, aging populations, and political gridlock, while emerging-market economies that had been helped somewhat by a weaker dollar are showing signs of strain.

item.title: France’s Far-Right Reckoning Is Delayed, Not Denied
item.description: Following weeks of political chaos stemming from a seemingly irresolvable budget debate, French President Emmanuel Macron must decide whether to call a snap legislative election now or allow for continued paralysis until the presidential election in 2027. Either way, the far right will have its best shot ever at winning power.

item.title: Financial Investors Can’t Profit From Complacency Forever
item.description: Despite the Trump administration’s systematic erosion of America’s capacity to create wealth over the long term, bond markets and investors seem to have fallen asleep at the wheel. But their complacency is not the result of ignorance; it is a highly profitable – and extremely risky – choice.

item.title: The Prisoner of Memory
item.description: Albanian-born political theorist Lea Ypi has built her reputation on turning the ruins of communism into poignant meditations on freedom and dignity. Her new book presents a moving portrait of her grandmother, though its reliance on fictionalized scenes undermines the power of lived memory.

item.title: Trump’s Misrule of Law
item.description: US President Donald Trump’s threat to invoke the Insurrection Act and have Democratic state officials arrested is just the latest escalation in his assault on the rule of law at home and abroad. With an increasingly Trump-aligned media, the US Congress, and the US Supreme Court actively supporting and even facilitating his lawless behavior, resistance is becoming more urgent – and more difficult – by the day.

item.title: The Big Picture
The Case for IMF Gold Sales
item.description: It is hard to imagine a more cost-effective solution to foreign-aid cuts than the International Monetary Fund selling a small share of its vast gold reserves, worth over $350 billion. The finance ministers and central bankers attending the IMF and World Bank's annual meetings must act swiftly to take advantage of record-high gold prices.

item.title: Macron’s Tragedy
item.description: The tragedy of Emmanuel Macron’s presidency is that what was billed as an alternative to hyper-partisanship has only deepened partisanship. And his campaign to forge a new consensus only created a consensus against his presidency.

item.title: Afghanistan’s Ban on Girls’ Education Goes Online
item.description: To evade the Taliban’s ban on female secondary education, Afghan girls and women have flocked to online courses. But a recent two-day internet blackout in Afghanistan, which briefly cut off this crucial lifeline, could be the start of a worrying expansion of the regime’s gender apartheid.

item.title: The EU Must Stand Up to Trump
item.description: It makes no sense for an economic bloc as large as the European Union to fold to a reckless US president who is driven entirely by personal obsessions and whose word means nothing. European values are too important to be traded away, and trading them away to such a leader won't accomplish anything.

item.title: Windmill Wars
item.description: Opposition from local communities has emerged as a major barrier to expanding wind-power capacity in many countries. While the courts might seem to offer the best path to overcoming this barrier, financial compensation for affected households is likely to be faster, cheaper, and less contentious.

item.title: Rethinking Value-Added Taxes for Developing Economies
item.description: For decades, the VAT has been a cornerstone of tax systems worldwide, providing governments with a stable source of revenue and fiscal flexibility. But in many countries, it has not replaced lost tariff income and has encouraged exports of raw materials, highlighting the need to align tax policy with national development priorities.

item.title: Green Shipping Could Mean a Green Africa
item.description: As the International Maritime Organization gathers to adopt its Net-Zero Framework, which includes a binding emissions-pricing mechanism, it must begin thinking about how to distribute the resulting revenues equitably. Ideally, the funds would be used to unlock Africa’s green-energy potential.

item.title: A Paradigm Shift on Animal Testing
item.description: Since the 1938 Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, the US has required animal testing to predict human outcomes for all drug, therapy, cosmetic, and food safety reviews and approvals. But the authorities are finally acknowledging what industry leaders have long known: animal testing is cruel, costly, and ineffective.

item.title: America’s “Warrior” Ethos Won't Protect Europe
item.description: For the Trump administration, “America First” is no mere slogan; it is a policy ethos that justifies inward-looking, capricious, and transactional approaches with no basis in rules, norms, or values. While many countries are adjusting to this new strategic reality, the EU's response leaves much to be desired.

item.title: The World Must Not Ignore Israel’s Attacks on Gaza’s Hospitals
item.description: Over the last two years, the Israeli government has repeatedly violated international humanitarian law, particularly in its systematic attacks on Gaza’s medical facilities and personnel. To uphold the rules of war, the UN Security Council should adopt a resolution that highlights attacks on health-care infrastructure globally.

item.title: Forbidden Jokes
item.description: Last month, ABC suspended late-night talk show host Jimmy Kimmel – a frequent critic of US President Donald Trump – after pressure from the government. While Kimmel was reinstated, Trump will likely continue to threaten comedians, because nothing is more damaging to a demagogue than being laughed at.

item.title: Putin’s Polycrisis
item.description: Despite mounting economic and demographic pressures, Russian President Vladimir Putin will continue to feed the war machine so long as he gains ground in Ukraine. To change his calculus, Western leaders must strengthen sanctions against the Kremlin, provide advanced weapons to Ukraine, and incentivize Russian brain drain.
